rev.diff:
Line 35: Line 35:
===Biodamper===
===Biodamper===
â
[[File:Biodamper.jpg|200px|thumb|Biodamper]]
 
An item intended to screen the wearer from certain kinds of detection. A biodamper resembling a [[ring (jewellery)|ring]] is placed on [[Donna Noble]]'s finger in "[[The Runaway Bride (Doctor Who)|The Runaway Bride]]", but [[Doctor (Doctor Who)|the Doctor]] later realises it is ineffective, because Donna had been infused with [[List of Doctor Who items#Huon particles|Huon particles]].
An item intended to screen the wearer from certain kinds of detection. A biodamper resembling a [[ring (jewellery)|ring]] is placed on [[Donna Noble]]'s finger in "[[The Runaway Bride (Doctor Who)|The Runaway Bride]]", but [[Doctor (Doctor Who)|the Doctor]] later realises it is ineffective, because Donna had been infused with [[List of Doctor Who items#Huon particles|Huon particles]].
Line 58: Line 57:
===Chameleon Arch===
===Chameleon Arch===
â
[[File:Chameleon arch.jpg|200px|thumb|The Chameleon Arch]]
 
The Chameleon Arch is a device that rewrites every cell of an individual to a specific species. The conversion, which causes extreme pain, also provides a set of false memories to match the new persona. The [[Tenth Doctor]] uses it in "[[Human Nature (Doctor Who episode)|Human Nature]]", enabling him to hide from the [[Family of Blood]] in 1913 as the school teacher, John Smith. He retains a small amount of "residual awareness", resulting in dreams about his life before the change. The Chameleon Arch stores the Doctor's Time Lord identity in a [[#F|fob watch]] that slots into the device as it is operated. In "[[Utopia (Doctor Who)|Utopia]]", Martha discovers that [[Master (Doctor Who)|The Master]] used the same process, generating "Professor Yana" as his persona.
The Chameleon Arch is a device that rewrites every cell of an individual to a specific species. The conversion, which causes extreme pain, also provides a set of false memories to match the new persona. The [[Tenth Doctor]] uses it in "[[Human Nature (Doctor Who episode)|Human Nature]]", enabling him to hide from the [[Family of Blood]] in 1913 as the school teacher, John Smith. He retains a small amount of "residual awareness", resulting in dreams about his life before the change. The Chameleon Arch stores the Doctor's Time Lord identity in a [[#F|fob watch]] that slots into the device as it is operated. In "[[Utopia (Doctor Who)|Utopia]]", Martha discovers that [[Master (Doctor Who)|The Master]] used the same process, generating "Professor Yana" as his persona.
Line 196: Line 194:
===Huon particles===
===Huon particles===
{{See also|The Runaway Bride (Doctor Who)}}
{{See also|The Runaway Bride (Doctor Who)}}
â
[[File:Huon particles.jpg|300px|thumb|The Doctor activating a vial of Huon particles]]
 
Ancient particles from the Dark Times. They are potentially deadly and contain a great amount of energy. Huon particles will attract other sets of Huon particles, causing infused people or objects to teleport. A remnant of Huon particles exist in the heart of the TARDIS.
Ancient particles from the Dark Times. They are potentially deadly and contain a great amount of energy. Huon particles will attract other sets of Huon particles, causing infused people or objects to teleport. A remnant of Huon particles exist in the heart of the TARDIS.
Line 228: Line 225:
===Jelly babies===
===Jelly babies===
â
[[Image:Jelly babies.jpg|thumb|100px|Jelly babies]]
 
[[Jelly baby|Jelly babies]] are a confectionery favoured by a few versions of the Doctor. The [[Master (Doctor Who)|Master]] is also seen eating jelly babies in the "[[The Sound of Drums]]". Both the Doctor and the Master are seen offering them to other people.
[[Jelly baby|Jelly babies]] are a confectionery favoured by a few versions of the Doctor. The [[Master (Doctor Who)|Master]] is also seen eating jelly babies in the "[[The Sound of Drums]]". Both the Doctor and the Master are seen offering them to other people.
===Jethrik===
===Jethrik===
â
[[File:Jethrik.jpg|thumb|Jethrik]]
 
An extremely valuable mineral. A small piece can power an entire fleet of battleships. One of the pieces of [[The Key to Time]] was disguised as a lump of Jethrik in ''[[The Ribos Operation]]''.
An extremely valuable mineral. A small piece can power an entire fleet of battleships. One of the pieces of [[The Key to Time]] was disguised as a lump of Jethrik in ''[[The Ribos Operation]]''.
===''A Journal of Impossible Things''===
===''A Journal of Impossible Things''===
â
[[File:Past Doctors section.jpg|thumb|The page from ''A Journal of Impossible Things''.]]
 
A [[Dream journal|dream diary]], containing notes and sketches by the [[Tenth Doctor]]'s human persona, John Smith, in "[[Human Nature (Doctor Who episode)|Human Nature]]"/"[[The Family of Blood]]". The title is handwritten on the journal's first page. Referred to by Smith as "stories", it is shown on screen as scribbled words and what appear to be charcoal pencil sketches, recording what Smith remembers from dreams about his adventures as the Doctor. Joan Redfern retains the ''Journal'' at the end of "The Family of Blood", and it is eventually published in 2009 by her granddaughter in [[The End of Time]].
A [[Dream journal|dream diary]], containing notes and sketches by the [[Tenth Doctor]]'s human persona, John Smith, in "[[Human Nature (Doctor Who episode)|Human Nature]]"/"[[The Family of Blood]]". The title is handwritten on the journal's first page. Referred to by Smith as "stories", it is shown on screen as scribbled words and what appear to be charcoal pencil sketches, recording what Smith remembers from dreams about his adventures as the Doctor. Joan Redfern retains the ''Journal'' at the end of "The Family of Blood", and it is eventually published in 2009 by her granddaughter in [[The End of Time]].
Line 256: Line 250:
==L==
==L==
===Laser screwdriver===
===Laser screwdriver===
â
[[File:Master with laser screwdriver.png|The Master's Laser Screwdriver|thumb|100px]]
 
A weapon used by [[Master (Doctor Who)|the Master]] in "[[The Sound of Drums]]" which resembles the Doctor's [[sonic screwdriver]]. It can kill with a directed laser beam or artificially age a target (provided the device has a blueprint of the victim's biological imprint) using a smaller version of the [[#H|Hypersonic Sound Wave Manipulator]] technology designed by Professor Richard Lazarus. It is built with isomorphic controls, preventing anyone but the Master from using it. It was removed from the Master by the Doctor using telekinesis and has not been seen since. A toy version was produced.
A weapon used by [[Master (Doctor Who)|the Master]] in "[[The Sound of Drums]]" which resembles the Doctor's [[sonic screwdriver]]. It can kill with a directed laser beam or artificially age a target (provided the device has a blueprint of the victim's biological imprint) using a smaller version of the [[#H|Hypersonic Sound Wave Manipulator]] technology designed by Professor Richard Lazarus. It is built with isomorphic controls, preventing anyone but the Master from using it. It was removed from the Master by the Doctor using telekinesis and has not been seen since. A toy version was produced.
Line 291: Line 284:
==N==
==N==
===Nanogenes===
===Nanogenes===
â
[[File:Nanogenes.jpg|thumb|Nanogenes]]
 
[[Nanorobotics|Nanotechnological]] robots which can heal damaged tissue. They are Chula technology, seen in "[[The Empty Child]]" and "[[The Doctor Dances]]". The nanogenes are designed to heal soldiers and ready them for battle, making them [[List of Doctor Who items#O|Om-com]] capable. Without a complete template for a species, the nanogenes restored the Jamie with a gas mask fused to his face, and replicate the gas mask and Jamie's other injuries to anyone Jamie touched.
[[Nanorobotics|Nanotechnological]] robots which can heal damaged tissue. They are Chula technology, seen in "[[The Empty Child]]" and "[[The Doctor Dances]]". The nanogenes are designed to heal soldiers and ready them for battle, making them [[List of Doctor Who items#O|Om-com]] capable. Without a complete template for a species, the nanogenes restored the Jamie with a gas mask fused to his face, and replicate the gas mask and Jamie's other injuries to anyone Jamie touched.
Line 308: Line 300:
===Osterhagen key===
===Osterhagen key===
â
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:OsterhargenKey.jpg|thumb|100px|The Osterhagen Key]] -->
 
The Osterhagen (an anagram of "Earth's Gone") key is a priming device controlled by [[Unified Intelligence Taskforce|UNIT]] for a series of 25 nuclear warheads placed beneath the Earth's crust at strategic points, for use at a time when Earth's destruction is preferable to the alternative. Osterhagan stations are located in [[Alaska]], [[Argentina]], [[China]], [[Germany]] and [[Liberia]]. To be activated, at least three Osterhagen bases must be online. The key was given to [[Martha Jones]] by UNIT in "[[The Stolen Earth (Doctor Who)|The Stolen Earth]]", but was lost when she was brought by [[transmat]] on board the Dalek Crucible. Martha explained that the Osterhagen Key was to be used "if the suffering of the human race was so great, so without hope, then it became the final option". The Doctor requested that Martha get rid of the Osterhagen system.
The Osterhagen (an anagram of "Earth's Gone") key is a priming device controlled by [[Unified Intelligence Taskforce|UNIT]] for a series of 25 nuclear warheads placed beneath the Earth's crust at strategic points, for use at a time when Earth's destruction is preferable to the alternative. Osterhagan stations are located in [[Alaska]], [[Argentina]], [[China]], [[Germany]] and [[Liberia]]. To be activated, at least three Osterhagen bases must be online. The key was given to [[Martha Jones]] by UNIT in "[[The Stolen Earth (Doctor Who)|The Stolen Earth]]", but was lost when she was brought by [[transmat]] on board the Dalek Crucible. Martha explained that the Osterhagen Key was to be used "if the suffering of the human race was so great, so without hope, then it became the final option". The Doctor requested that Martha get rid of the Osterhagen system.
==P==
==P==
===Paradox machine===
===Paradox machine===
â
[[File:Paradox machine.jpg|200px|thumb|The Paradox Machine]]
 
Designed by the Master in "[[The Sound of Drums]]", the device is constructed from the Doctor's [[TARDIS]], centred around the main console with several large pipes leading into it, installed on the airborne aircraft carrier ''[[List of Doctor Who vehicles#Valiant|Valiant]]''. The paradox machine uses the power of the TARDIS to prevent the universe from collapsing under the inherent logical contradiction of a [[grandfather paradox]] when the Toclafane kill their ancestors, modern day humans. When destroyed, it has the effect of reversing time up to the point immediately before it was originally activated. Those in proximity of the "[[Eye (cyclone)|eye of the storm]]" of the device, the radius of which is at least sufficient to encompass the ''Valiant'', are immune to its effect. Jack Harkness destroyed the paradox machine with a machine gun.
Designed by the Master in "[[The Sound of Drums]]", the device is constructed from the Doctor's [[TARDIS]], centred around the main console with several large pipes leading into it, installed on the airborne aircraft carrier ''[[List of Doctor Who vehicles#Valiant|Valiant]]''. The paradox machine uses the power of the TARDIS to prevent the universe from collapsing under the inherent logical contradiction of a [[grandfather paradox]] when the Toclafane kill their ancestors, modern day humans. When destroyed, it has the effect of reversing time up to the point immediately before it was originally activated. Those in proximity of the "[[Eye (cyclone)|eye of the storm]]" of the device, the radius of which is at least sufficient to encompass the ''Valiant'', are immune to its effect. Jack Harkness destroyed the paradox machine with a machine gun.
Line 325: Line 315:
===President's gauntlet===
===President's gauntlet===
â
[[File:Glove of Rassilon.jpg|President's Gauntlet|thumb|100px]]A metal glove used by the Lord President of Gallifrey in "[[The End of Time]]". It is used to disintegrate a female Time Lord when she goes against the wishes of the Lord President, and to revert the Master's actions, restoring the human race to normal.
+
A metal glove used by the Lord President of Gallifrey in "[[The End of Time]]". It is used to disintegrate a female Time Lord when she goes against the wishes of the Lord President, and to revert the Master's actions, restoring the human race to normal.
===Progenation machine===
===Progenation machine===
Line 363: Line 353:
===Reality Bomb===
===Reality Bomb===
â
[[File:Reality bomb.jpg|thumb|The Reality Bomb|100px]]
 
A device created by [[Davros]] and the [[Daleks]] which they prepared to use in "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]". It was meant to disrupt the electrical bond between all atoms in every form of matter, using Z-neutrino energy compressed into a single string by an alignment of 27 planets, therefore destroying the whole of the universe and all other universes via a rift at the heart of the Medusa Cascade. It was, however, disabled by [[Donna Noble|Donna]].
A device created by [[Davros]] and the [[Daleks]] which they prepared to use in "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]". It was meant to disrupt the electrical bond between all atoms in every form of matter, using Z-neutrino energy compressed into a single string by an alignment of 27 planets, therefore destroying the whole of the universe and all other universes via a rift at the heart of the Medusa Cascade. It was, however, disabled by [[Donna Noble|Donna]].
Line 389: Line 378:
In the 2007 episode "[[Blink (Doctor Who)|Blink]]" the Doctor retrieves his TARDIS after losing it by means of a security disk. This was essentially a DVD with specific code compatible to the TARDIS. He entrusts the DVD to Sally Sparrow, who inserts the disk into the TARDIS console, causing it to dematerialise, leaving her and Larry Nightingale behind. The security disk is valid for one journey. The TARDIS seems to automatically detect these disks and generates an accompanying hologram of the Doctor to announce this detection as a result.
In the 2007 episode "[[Blink (Doctor Who)|Blink]]" the Doctor retrieves his TARDIS after losing it by means of a security disk. This was essentially a DVD with specific code compatible to the TARDIS. He entrusts the DVD to Sally Sparrow, who inserts the disk into the TARDIS console, causing it to dematerialise, leaving her and Larry Nightingale behind. The security disk is valid for one journey. The TARDIS seems to automatically detect these disks and generates an accompanying hologram of the Doctor to announce this detection as a result.
â
[[Image:doctors severed hand.jpg|thumb|The Tenth Doctor's severed hand]]
 
===Severed hand===
===Severed hand===
:''See also: [[List of Torchwood items#Severed hand]]''
:''See also: [[List of Torchwood items#Severed hand]]''
Line 488: Line 476:
==="Timey-wimey" detector===
==="Timey-wimey" detector===
â
[[File:Timey wimey detector.jpg|thumb|Timey-Wimey Detector]]
 
A detector of temporal disturbances constructed by the Tenth Doctor in "[[Blink (Doctor Who)|Blink]]" when he and Martha Jones are sent back to 1969 without the TARDIS by the [[List of Doctor Who monsters and aliens#Weeping Angels|Weeping Angels]]. The unserious sounding name appears to be the Doctor's joking reference to his own inability to describe temporal theory in succinct layman's terms; he describes its operation as "Goes ding when there's stuff." He also says it can boil eggs at thirty paces, whether the user wants it to or not, and that he has therefore learned to avoid [[chicken|hens]]. Visible elements of the device's construction include a [[lunchbox]], a [[Handset|telephone handset]], some [[Magnetic tape|tape reels]], a [[postcard]], and the Doctor's [[sonic screwdriver]].
A detector of temporal disturbances constructed by the Tenth Doctor in "[[Blink (Doctor Who)|Blink]]" when he and Martha Jones are sent back to 1969 without the TARDIS by the [[List of Doctor Who monsters and aliens#Weeping Angels|Weeping Angels]]. The unserious sounding name appears to be the Doctor's joking reference to his own inability to describe temporal theory in succinct layman's terms; he describes its operation as "Goes ding when there's stuff." He also says it can boil eggs at thirty paces, whether the user wants it to or not, and that he has therefore learned to avoid [[chicken|hens]]. Visible elements of the device's construction include a [[lunchbox]], a [[Handset|telephone handset]], some [[Magnetic tape|tape reels]], a [[postcard]], and the Doctor's [[sonic screwdriver]].
Line 537: Line 524:
===Vortex manipulator===
===Vortex manipulator===
â
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Vortex Manipulator.jpg|thumb|right|250px| Captain Jack Harkness's Vortex Manipulator.]] -->
 
A more primitive form of time-travel technology, a vortex manipulator allows the user to travel through time by minimally controllable (and apparently uncomfortable) "hops" through the [[Time vortex (Doctor Who)|Time Vortex]]. The technology is compact enough to be worn on one's person easily, such as the [[List of Torchwood items#Time Agent Wrist-Strap|wrist-mounted device]] in the possession of [[Jack Harkness]], which he obtained during his stint as a Time Agent. The [[List of Doctor Who villains#Family of Blood|Family of Blood]] also had one capable of moving a small spaceship. When Jack notes that such technology means the Doctor is not the only person capable of traveling through time, the Doctor disdainfully compares the "[[space hopper]]" vortex manipulator to his "[[sports car]]" [[TARDIS]]. The device also allows travel through space by harnessing the energies of wormholes (such as the [[Cardiff Rift]]), as demonstrated by [[List of Torchwood characters#Captain John Hart|Captain John Hart]] and [[List of Torchwood characters#Gray|Gray]] in series 2 of ''[[Torchwood]]''. As seen in "[[The Sound of Drums]]", the Manipulator can also be programmed to teleport its operator (and anyone hanging on) from place to place once the Doctor has used his [[sonic screwdriver]] to jump-start it. The Doctor disables Jack's manipulator at the end of "[[Last of the Time Lords]]", but Jack figures out how to re-enable it (or at least restore its teleport function) in "[[The Stolen Earth]]". In the last episode of the 2008 series "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]" the Doctor once again disables Jack's vortex manipulator with his [[sonic screwdriver]]. In the final episode of "[[Children of Earth]]", it is revealed that the Vortex Manipulator (or at least Jack's) is indestructible, capable of surviving an explosion that destroyed the Torchwood Three building. In "[[The Pandorica Opens]]," [[River Song (Doctor Who)|River Song]] gets a vortex manipulator from a black market dealer in order to meet up with the Doctor, the dialogue suggests the manipulator is still on the disembodied hand of a Time Agent. River is able to use it to travel wherever she wants with no apparent problems. Later, the manipulator ends up in the hands of the Doctor who uses it to travel back in time and have the Auton copy of [[Rory Williams]] free himself trapped in the Pandorica. As the TARDIS is destroyed, the Doctor uses it to teleport through time, traveling to 1996 to meet up with the resurrected Amy Pond then using it to travel back in time to set the events in motion by giving Rory the screwdriver and leaving young Amy the notes that led her to the Pandorica. After learning River is still alive and is trapped in a time loop in the destroyed TARDIS (an emergency protocol to protect anyone inside), the Doctor is able to teleport into the TARDIS and rescue her. The Doctor later uses the manipulator to travel back in time 12 minutes to trick a [[Dalek]] and then pilot the Pandorica into the heart of the TARDIS explosion. After he is brought back from being erased from existence, the Doctor returns the manipulator to River who uses it to teleport away, presumably back to her own time.
A more primitive form of time-travel technology, a vortex manipulator allows the user to travel through time by minimally controllable (and apparently uncomfortable) "hops" through the [[Time vortex (Doctor Who)|Time Vortex]]. The technology is compact enough to be worn on one's person easily, such as the [[List of Torchwood items#Time Agent Wrist-Strap|wrist-mounted device]] in the possession of [[Jack Harkness]], which he obtained during his stint as a Time Agent. The [[List of Doctor Who villains#Family of Blood|Family of Blood]] also had one capable of moving a small spaceship. When Jack notes that such technology means the Doctor is not the only person capable of traveling through time, the Doctor disdainfully compares the "[[space hopper]]" vortex manipulator to his "[[sports car]]" [[TARDIS]]. The device also allows travel through space by harnessing the energies of wormholes (such as the [[Cardiff Rift]]), as demonstrated by [[List of Torchwood characters#Captain John Hart|Captain John Hart]] and [[List of Torchwood characters#Gray|Gray]] in series 2 of ''[[Torchwood]]''. As seen in "[[The Sound of Drums]]", the Manipulator can also be programmed to teleport its operator (and anyone hanging on) from place to place once the Doctor has used his [[sonic screwdriver]] to jump-start it. The Doctor disables Jack's manipulator at the end of "[[Last of the Time Lords]]", but Jack figures out how to re-enable it (or at least restore its teleport function) in "[[The Stolen Earth]]". In the last episode of the 2008 series "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]" the Doctor once again disables Jack's vortex manipulator with his [[sonic screwdriver]]. In the final episode of "[[Children of Earth]]", it is revealed that the Vortex Manipulator (or at least Jack's) is indestructible, capable of surviving an explosion that destroyed the Torchwood Three building. In "[[The Pandorica Opens]]," [[River Song (Doctor Who)|River Song]] gets a vortex manipulator from a black market dealer in order to meet up with the Doctor, the dialogue suggests the manipulator is still on the disembodied hand of a Time Agent. River is able to use it to travel wherever she wants with no apparent problems. Later, the manipulator ends up in the hands of the Doctor who uses it to travel back in time and have the Auton copy of [[Rory Williams]] free himself trapped in the Pandorica. As the TARDIS is destroyed, the Doctor uses it to teleport through time, traveling to 1996 to meet up with the resurrected Amy Pond then using it to travel back in time to set the events in motion by giving Rory the screwdriver and leaving young Amy the notes that led her to the Pandorica. After learning River is still alive and is trapped in a time loop in the destroyed TARDIS (an emergency protocol to protect anyone inside), the Doctor is able to teleport into the TARDIS and rescue her. The Doctor later uses the manipulator to travel back in time 12 minutes to trick a [[Dalek]] and then pilot the Pandorica into the heart of the TARDIS explosion. After he is brought back from being erased from existence, the Doctor returns the manipulator to River who uses it to teleport away, presumably back to her own time.
==W==
==W==
===Warpstar===
===Warpstar===
â
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:WarpStar.jpg|thumb|25px|Warp Star]] -->
 
A small crystalline device carried by [[Sarah Jane Smith]] in "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]" that looks like a necklace, but is in fact a highly explosive device (a "Warp-fold conjugation") inside a carbonised shell. According to Sarah Jane, it was given to her by a Verran soothsayer to be used at "the end of days". Jack Harkness wires it into the Dalek Crucible's mainframe and threatens to use it; however, he does not get the opportunity as the Daleks swiftly transmat Jack, Sarah Jane, and their companions away.
A small crystalline device carried by [[Sarah Jane Smith]] in "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]" that looks like a necklace, but is in fact a highly explosive device (a "Warp-fold conjugation") inside a carbonised shell. According to Sarah Jane, it was given to her by a Verran soothsayer to be used at "the end of days". Jack Harkness wires it into the Dalek Crucible's mainframe and threatens to use it; however, he does not get the opportunity as the Daleks swiftly transmat Jack, Sarah Jane, and their companions away.
